reviewText: This game is alright. I'm all for trying something new when it comes to a predefined genre. However, the spinning of the map just didn't fit for me personally. I'm sure many people will enjoy it and that is fine. I'm just not a fan of puzzle games and I feel like that's what this feature brings to the game. I found it very tedious and it quickly ruined the overall Tower Defense experience for me. Tower Defense is probably my favorite genre and without the map rotations feature, this would have been right up my alley. For me personally I would rate it 6/10.

reviewText: Sleep attack is mix between a puzzle game and a tower defense, and it does so well. You can tell alot of love was put into this game, the art is superb for what it is. However, the soundtrack did seem to be lacking in alot of areas, it seems to loop rather quickly. But the gameplay has good bit of variety in terms of your towers the enemy, also upgrading your towers gives a nice visual difference for each one, which I can appreciate . Also the whole twist the map" thing is actually a good way to stop the gameplay from getting stale
date: you have to actively be involved if you want to move forward. If this were a mobile game I would definitely buy it
recommended: it has a the gimmicks of a good ol' time waster

reviewText: I have played many Tower Defense games in the past, but I can definitely say without a doubt that Sleep Attack is THE best one I've played by far! Not only does it have bright, vibrant colors that catches the eye, but it also has fun, quirky music that immediately puts a smile to my face. Furthermore, Sleep Attack has a great puzzle/strategy aspect to it that challenges your mind a bit more than a typical Tower Defense game would, so it‚Äôs great for people who want something thats been revamped. And although at times it can become pretty difficult (especially with controlling the map) I, personally, think it makes the game even more worth buying because of how innovated it is. Overall, I would highly recommend Sleep Attack to gamers that enjoy a challenge and want something new from the original Tower Defense genre.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A cool Tower Defense game with a twist.... literary.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gZHzLw9s9ac

You control the layout of the battlefield, and you decide the paths your enemies follow! Build and place powerful turrets to attack invading enemies. Then rotate the battlefield to force foes down your preferred path of destruction. Be careful though, there are always multiple routes to control!

Combine tactical planning with strategic tower upgrades to slow, divert and damage your enemies. Carefully choose the placement and upgrade levels of your towers, as each turret possesses unique strengths and weaknesses. Simply swipe to change the routes your enemies take, allowing each tower to cause maximum carnage! - Recommended!
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sleep Attack  ‚Äì A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good
Vibrant graphics
Nice gameplay tweak on an old recipe. Controlling the map really changes the dynamic
Has the addictiveness inherent to tower defense games The not so good:
This type of gameplay is way more suited for touchscreen devices. With the mouse it‚Äôs pretty frantic.
The conclusion:
In a world filled with tower defense games,  Sleep Attack brings a nice twist to this tired genre. With cute graphics and colorful environments, this game shouldn‚Äôt be missed by the fans of the genre. It plays awesome on laptops with touchscreen.
You can see me playing here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=45w6u8iTtlw

reviewText: Very slick mobile game which unfortunately hasn't put in the work needed for a PC interface (Eg. Still has mobile GUI, functions like rotating could be mapped to keys).  It's ok on PC but would be infinitely better on a portable touch screen.  This is more a neautral review because it is a good game but this is just the wrong platform (it's on Android and iOS though so check it out there).
